evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing. After the collision, she suggested not moving the aircraft off the blast fence.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

slot_statements.availability: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was present and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal event on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: There is no evidence contradicting the presence of communication/coordination breakdown among crew in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal event, indicating strong defeater resistance for this root cause.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal event, such as misaligned task execution and delayed information sharing.

slot_statements.availability: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and observable within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal phase on 12-25.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The identification of the procedural deviation in pushback execution withstands potential counterarguments or alternative explanations, supported by consistent evidence from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal data on 12-25.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The procedural deviation aligns with key features identified in pushback operations, including timing, communication protocols, and equipment handling specific to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal phase.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew was present and observable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal event on 12-25.

assumptions: Communication/coordination breakdown is inferred from lack of warnings and assumptions by crew members despite observable cues.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, timely communication and coordinated actions preventing the incident, or if mechanical failure was the primary cause.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
She did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8, H10, and H12 indicate lack of effective communication and coordination among crew during pushback, supporting the presence of communication/coordination breakdown.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity exists about whether procedural deviations or communication breakdowns were primary cause; evidence does not fully exclude procedural deviation.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and observable within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal phase on 12-25.

assumptions: The TRP ground markings and their significance are correctly identified and understood
The history accounts accurately reflect the sequence of events and roles of involved personnel
defeaters: If evidence showed the continued movement was due to mechanical control failure or environmental factors rather than procedural deviation
If communication breakdown was proven to be the primary cause rather than procedural deviation

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Multiple history items (H2, H3, H4, H8, H10, H12) document the procedural deviation during pushback execution, including the tug instructor taking over, continuing past the TRP, and hitting the blast barrier, supporting the claim of documented and observable procedural deviation.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Potential ambiguity in communication signals and lack of explicit warnings from wingman or headset operator

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features observed in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal event, such as misaligned task execution and delayed information sharing.

assumptions: The described behaviors reflect communication/coordination breakdown as key features
No contradictory evidence indicating mechanical failure or procedural deviation as primary cause
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, timely communication and coordination among crew preventing the incident
If environmental or marking deficiencies were shown to be the primary cause rather than crew communication breakdown

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

node.statement: There is no evidence contradicting the presence of communication/coordination breakdown among crew in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal event, indicating strong defeater resistance for this root cause.

assumptions: No mechanical faults were reported or evident in the evidence items provided.
defeaters: If evidence showed hardware faults or mechanical control failures causing the event, or if clear communication and coordination were documented without breakdown.

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.
He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.
He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H3, H8, H10, and H12 show active communication attempts but also reveal lack of warnings or challenges about the pushback continuing past the TRP, supporting communication breakdown as the root cause and no contradicting evidence for mechanical failure.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in interpreting crew interactions and possible unreported mechanical issues

node.statement: The procedural deviation aligns with key features identified in pushback operations, including timing, communication protocols, and equipment handling specific to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal phase.

assumptions: The TRP ground markings and their visibility are adequate as per H7 and H13
The procedural deviation is distinct from environmental or mechanical causes based on evidence
defeaters: If evidence showed environmental markings or visibility were inadequate causing the deviation
If communication protocols were fully followed and no procedural errors occurred
If mechanical control failures were documented as cause

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view.
The wingman... commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence (H4, H8, H13) shows the procedural deviation involved timing and communication issues around the TRP and equipment handling consistent with key features of pushback operations for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA, supporting the claim.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Ambiguity in communication effectiveness and small TRP size impact

slot_statements.availability: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and identifiable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal context.
slot_statements.defeater_resistance: The environmental or marking deficiency must be resistant to defeaters within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal context.
slot_statements.fit_to_key_features: The environmental or marking deficiency should align with the key features relevant to the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal scenario.

node.statement: The environmental or marking deficiency must be present and identifiable in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA 12-25 hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal context.

assumptions: The TRP marking visibility and adequacy are critical to identifying environmental or marking deficiency.
Crew statements about visual signals and marking size imply marking deficiency.
defeaters: If evidence showed the TRP markings were clearly visible and adequate to all crew members, or if procedural deviations fully explained the event without marking issues.

quotes.exact_quote: The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tugs brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
Headset operator The headset operator was also qualified as a wingman. Prior to this accident, he knew about TRPs from his training for the headset operator role but had not physically seen one.

Wingman The wingman was also a qualified headset operator. On the day of the accident, he had been called into work at short notice. To avoid delaying the pushback, he had not collected the marshalling wands from the tug. Nevertheless, it was not mandatory to use them. He commented that the TRP was quite small.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H7, H8, H11, and H13 directly describe the presence and visibility of the TRP marking and its adequacy, supporting that an environmental or marking deficiency was present and identifiable in the context.
outcome.uncertainty_source: Some ambiguity in crew awareness and use of visual signals; no explicit statement that markings were inadequate but implied by small size and lack of physical sighting by headset operator.

node.statement: The identification of the procedural deviation in pushback execution withstands potential counterarguments or alternative explanations, supported by consistent evidence from the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA hist_pair_engine_t3_prefinal data on 12-25.

assumptions: No mechanical control failure occurred as no evidence indicates such faults.
Crew communications and actions as described are accurate and complete.
defeaters: If evidence showed equipment fault traces or bench checks indicating control malfunction, this would challenge the procedural deviation claim.
If communication or coordination failures were documented as primary causes, this would weaken the procedural deviation attribution.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

The trainee driver reported that she felt the tug slow down as the aircraft’s nose wheel approached the TRP, so believed the instructor would stop the pushback. However, she did not say anything when he drove past the TRP, assuming he must have known what he was doing.

He commented that the tug instructor took over when the aircraft was abeam Stand 62 and thereafter was attending to talking to the trainee. The tug slowed down when the aircraft was abeam Stand 61, so he positioned himself to disconnect the tug from the aircraft when it stopped. However, the aircraft continued to move slowly until it hit the blast fence. He said he assumed the instructor had a reason for that and did not question his actions.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4, H8, H10, and H12 directly document the procedural deviation in pushback execution and the lack of mechanical control failure indications, supporting the claim that the procedural deviation withstands counterarguments.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct mechanical fault evidence is presented; assumptions rely on absence of such evidence and eyewitness accounts.
